id_1.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: How strong is the generalisation that if a president consistently insults a particular group, then that group will provide less information and cooperation in counter-terrorism efforts?

Is Clinton's assertion that "they're on the front lines" and can provide unique information to the US consistent with known evidence in the domain of counter-terrorism, and does she provide any concrete examples of instances where Muslim communities have provided crucial intelligence that couldn't be obtained elsewhere?
Is there some other case that is also similar to the relationship between the US and Muslim nations, but in which Donald's rhetoric has led to increased cooperation with those nations?

Is it not a contradiction for the speaker to emphasize the importance of working with Muslim nations and communities when they themselves have been critical of certain policies and actions of these countries in the past?

id_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of 'executives at the top sharing profits with the general workforce'?

Is the assertion that "we're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes" a genuine solution to the economic issues Clinton presented, considering the track record of previous administrations in implementing similar policies?
Is there some other case that is also similar to the wealthy executives having a significant share of the profits, but in which they are not able to share the profits with their employees?
Is it practically possible for the wealthy to pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes without significantly increasing taxes on the middle class?

id_3.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the economic recovery, such as government stimulus packages or technological advancements, that could have contributed to the improved economic state Clinton is referring to, rather than solely her proposed policies?
Is what Clinton means by "independent experts" genuinely objective and unbiased, considering her statement's context and potential conflict of interest?

Are there differences between Clinton's economic recovery and the economic recoveries of other countries that have implemented similar policies to those Clinton is proposing, that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between Clinton's economic recovery and those countries' recoveries?
Is going back to the policies that failed us in the first place practically possible, considering the significant economic and environmental challenges we've faced in the past?

id_4.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of NATO invoking Article 5 in response to a threat from another nation, considering that it was invoked in response to terrorism in Afghanistan rather than a direct threat from Iran?

Is the claim that Iran was "weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb" consistent with what other experts in the field of nuclear proliferation say, and is this assertion directly quoted from a credible source, or is it Clinton's interpretation of available information?
Is there some other case that is also similar to NATO's response to the 9/11 attack, but in which the alliance did not invoke Article 5?
Is it practically possible for the 28 nations of NATO to go to war with Iran in the event that Iran forms a nuclear bomb, given their existing commitments and resources?

id_5.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: Are there other factors in this particular case that could have interfered with the event of the sanctions imposed on Iran being effective in the long term, considering the deal made by John Kerry and President Obama ultimately allowed Iran to resume some nuclear activities?

Is what Clinton considers "diplomacy" and "coalition-building" consistent with known evidence in the domain of international relations, particularly in the context of Iran's nuclear program, and does it align with the perspectives of other experts in the field?

Are there differences between Clinton's diplomatic efforts with Iran and other cases where sanctions led to conflict, that would tend to undermine the force of the similarity cited between Clinton's approach and the outcome of the Iran nuclear deal?

Is it not good judgment for Clinton to imply that her successor, John Kerry, and President Obama were more effective in dealing with Iran's nuclear program, considering her own efforts in imposing sanctions took a year-and-a-half and required the involvement of Russia and China?
